monogr.title: The faithfvll shepheardesse : By Iohn Fletcher
monogr.author: Fletcher, John

div.head: To The Reader.
div.p: IF you be not reasonably assurde of your knowledge in this kinde of Poeme, lay downe the booke or read this, which I would wish had bene the prologue. It is a pastorall Tragic-come die, which the people seeing when it was plaid, hauing euer had a singuler guif • in defining, conclud • d to be a play of coūtry hired Shepheards, in gray cloakes, with curtaild dogs in strings, sometimes laughing together, and sometimes killing one another: And missing whitsun ales, creame, wa •••• & morris-dances, began to be angry. In their error I would not haue you fall, least you incurre their censur • . Vnderstand therefore a pastorall to be a representation of shepheards and shepheard desses, with their actions and passions, which must be such as may agree with their natures a • least not exceeding • ormer fictions, & v •• g • r traditions: they are not to be adorn'd with any art, but such improper ones as n • ture is s • id to bestow, as singing and Poetry, or such as experience may teach them, as the vertues of hearts, & fountaine the ordinary course of the Sun, moone, and starres, and such l • ke. But you are euer to remember S •• phe • ds to be such, a • all the ancient Poets and m • d • rne of vndersta • ding haue r •• eaued them: tha • is, the owners of flockes and not hyerlings A tragic-comedie is not so called in respect •• mirth and killing • but in respect it wants deat • s, which is inough to make it no tragedie, yet brings some neere it, which is inough to make it no comedie: which must be a representation of familiar people, with such kinde of trouble as no life be questiond, so that a God is as lawfull in this as in a tragedie, and meane people as in a comedie. Thus much I hope will serue to iustifie my Poem • , and make you v • derstand it, to teach you more for nothing, I do not know that I am in conscience bound.
